countermeasure.name: Get started with AWS managed policies and move toward least-privilege permissions
countermeasure.desc: To get started granting permissions to your users and workloads, use the AWS managed policies that grant permissions for many common use cases. They are available in your AWS account. Keep in mind that AWS managed policies might not grant least-privilege permissions for your specific use cases because they are available for use by all AWS customers. As a result, we recommend that you reduce permissions further by defining customer managed policies that are specific to your use cases. For more information, see AWS managed policies. For more information about AWS managed policies that are designed for specific job functions, see AWS managed policies for job functions.

countermeasure.name: Monitor access and usage
countermeasure.desc:
It's recommended to use your current tracking mechanisms to monitor, alert, and report the sign in and use of root user credentials, including alerts that announce root user sign-in and usage. The following services can help to ensure that root user credential usage is tracked and perform security checks that can help prevent unauthorized use.

If you want to be notified about root user sign-in activity in your account, you can leverage Amazon CloudWatch to create an Events rule that detects when root user credentials are used and triggers a notification to your security administrator. For details, see Monitor and notify on AWS account root user activity.

If you want to set up notifications to alert you of approved root user actions, you can leverage Amazon EventBridge along with Amazon SNS to write an EventBridge rule to track root user usage for the specific action and notify you using an Amazon SNS topic. For an example, see Send a notification when an Amazon S3 object is created.

If you already using GuardDuty as your threat detection service, you can extend its capability to notify you when root user credentials are being used in your account.

Alerts should include, but not be limited to, the email address for the root user. Have procedures in place for how to respond to alerts so that personnel who receive a root user access alert understand how to validate that root user access is expected, and how to escalate if they believe that a security incident is in progress. For an example of how to configure alerts, see Monitor and notify on AWS account root user activity.

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and remove unused users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials
countermeasure.desc: You might have IAM users, roles, permissions, policies, or credentials that you no longer need in your AWS account. IAM provides last accessed information to help you identify the users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials that you no longer need so that you can remove them. This helps you reduce the number of users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials that you have to monitor. You can also use this information to refine your IAM policies to better adhere to least-privilege permissions. For more information, see Refining permissions in AWS using last accessed information.

countermeasure.name: Require human users to use federation with an identity provider to access AWS using temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Human users, also known as human identities, are the people, administrators, developers, operators, and consumers of your applications. They must have an identity to access your AWS environments and applications. Human users that are members of your organization are also known as workforce identities. Human users can also be external users with whom you collaborate, and who interact with your AWS resources. They can do this via a web browser, client application, mobile app, or interactive command-line tools.

Require your human users to use temporary credentials when accessing AWS. You can use an identity provider for your human users to provide federated access to AWS accounts by assuming roles, which provide temporary credentials. For centralized access management, we recommend that you use AWS IAM Identity Center (IAM Identity Center) to manage access to your accounts and permissions within those accounts. You can manage your user identities with IAM Identity Center, or manage access permissions for user identities in IAM Identity Center from an external identity provider. For more information, see What is AWS IAM Identity Center in the AWS IAM Identity Center User Guide.

For more information about roles, see Roles terms and concepts.

countermeasure.name: Require multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend using IAM roles for human users and workloads that access your AWS resources so that they use temporary credentials. However, for scenarios in which you need an IAM user or root user in your account, require MFA for additional security. With MFA, users have a device that generates a response to an authentication challenge. Each user's credentials and device-generated response are required to complete the sign-in process. For more information, see Using multi-factor authentication (MFA) in AWS.

If you use IAM Identity Center for centralized access management for human users, you can use the IAM Identity Center MFA capabilities when your identity source is configured with the IAM Identity Center identity store, AWS Managed Microsoft AD, or AD Connector. For more information about MFA in IAM Identity Center see Multi-factor authentication in the AWS IAM Identity Center User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Require workloads to use temporary credentials with IAM roles to access AWS
countermeasure.desc:
A workload is a collection of resources and code that delivers business value, such as an application or backend process. Your workload can have applications, operational tools, and components that require an identity to make requests to AWS services, such as requests to read data. These identities include machines running in your AWS environments, such as Amazon EC2 instances or AWS Lambda functions.

You can also manage machine identities for external parties who need access. To give access to machine identities, you can use IAM roles. IAM roles have specific permissions and provide a way to access AWS by relying on temporary security credentials with a role session. Additionally, you might have machines outside of AWS that need access to your AWS environments. For machines that run outside of AWS you can use AWS Identity and Access Management Roles Anywhere. For more information about roles, see IAM roles. For details about how to use roles to delegate access across AWS accounts, see IAM tutorial: Delegate access across AWS accounts using IAM roles.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to account recovery mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure you develop a process to manage root user credential recovery mechanisms in case you need access to it during emergency such as takeover of your administrative account.

  • Ensure you have access to your root user email inbox so that you can reset a lost or forgotten root user password.
  • If MFA for your AWS account root user is lost, damaged, or not working, you can sign in using another MFA registered to the same root user credentials. If you lost access to all your MFAs, you need both the phone number and the email used to register your account, to be up to date and accessible to recover your MFA. For details, see Recovering a root user MFA device.
  • If you choose not to store your root user password and MFA, then the phone number registered in your account can be used as an alternate way to recover root user credentials. Ensure you have access to the contact phone number, keep the phone number updated, and limit who has access to manage the phone number.

No one person should have access to both the email inbox and phone number since both are verification channels to recover your root user password. It is important to have two groups of individuals managing these channels. One group having access to your primary email address and another group having access to the primary phone number to recover access to your account as root user.

countermeasure.name: Secure your Organizations account root user credentials
countermeasure.desc:
As you move to a multi-account strategy with Organizations, each of your AWS accounts has its own root user credentials that you need to secure. The account you use to create your organization is the management account and the rest of the accounts in your organization are member accounts.

Secure root user credentials for member accounts

If you use Organizations to manage multiple accounts, there are two strategies that you can take to secure root user access in your Organizations.

Secure root user credentials of your Organizations accounts with MFA.

Do not reset the root user password for your accounts, and only recover access to it when needed using the password reset process. When you create a member account in your organization, Organizations automatically creates an IAM role in the member account that allows the management account temporary access to the member account.

For details, see Accessing member accounts in your organization in the Organizations User Guide.

Set preventative security controls in Organizations using a service control policy (SCP)

If you use Organizations to manage multiple accounts, you can apply an SCP to restrict access to member account root user. Denying all root user actions in your member accounts, except for certain root-only actions, helps prevent unauthorized access. For details, see Use an SCP to restrict what the root user in your member accounts can do.

countermeasure.name: Secure your root user credentials to prevent unauthorized use
countermeasure.desc:
Secure your root user credentials and use them for only the tasks that require them. To help prevent unauthorized use, donâ€™t share your root user password, MFA, access keys, CloudFront key pairs, or signing certificates with anyone, except those that have a strict business need to access the root user.

Don't store the root user password with tools that depend on AWS services in an account that is accessed using that same password. If you lose or forget your root user password, you will not be able to access these tools. We recommend that you prioritize resiliency and consider requiring two or more people to authorize access to the storage location. Access to the password or its storage location should be logged and monitored.

countermeasure.name: Secure your root user sign-in with multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Because a root user can perform privileged actions, it's crucial to add MFA for the root user as a second authentication factor in addition to the email address and password as sign-in credentials. We strongly recommend enabling multiple MFA for your root user credentials to provide additional flexibility and resiliency in your security strategy. You can register up to eight MFA devices of any combination of the currently supported MFA types with your AWS account root user.

  • FIDO Certified hardware security keys are provided by third-party providers. For more information, see Enable a FIDO security key for the AWS account root user.
  • A hardware device that generates a six-digit numeric code based on the time-based one-time password (TOTP) algorithm. For more information, see Enable a hardware TOTP token for the AWS account root user.
  • A virtual authenticator application that runs on a phone or other device and emulates a physical device. For more information, see Enable a virtual MFA device for your AWS account root user.

countermeasure.name: Update access keys when needed for use cases that require long-term credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Where possible, we recommend relying on temporary credentials instead of creating long-term credentials such as access keys. However, for scenarios in which you need IAM users with programmatic access and long-term credentials, we recommend that you update the access keys when needed, such as when an employee leaves your company. We recommend that you use IAM access last used information to update and remove access keys safely. For more information, see Updating access keys.

There are specific use cases that require long-term credentials with IAM users in AWS. Some of the use cases include the following:

  • Workloads that cannot use IAM roles â€“ You might run a workload from a location that needs to access AWS. In some situations, you can't use IAM roles to provide temporary credentials, such as for WordPress plugins. In these situations, use IAM user long-term access keys for that workload to authenticate to AWS.
  • Third-party AWS clients â€“ If you are using tools that donâ€™t support access with IAM Identity Center, such as third-party AWS clients or vendors that are not hosted on AWS, use IAM user long-term access keys.
  • AWS CodeCommit access â€“ If you are using CodeCommit to store your code, you can use an IAM user with either SSH keys or service-specific credentials for CodeCommit to authenticate to your repositories. We recommend that you do this in addition to using a user in IAM Identity Center for normal authentication. Users in IAM Identity Center are the people in your workforce who need access to your AWS accounts or to your cloud applications. To give users access to your CodeCommit repositories without configuring IAM users, you can configure the git-remote-codecommit utility. For more information about IAM and CodeCommit, see Using IAM with CodeCommit: Git credentials, SSH keys, and AWS access keys. For more information about configuring the git-remote-codecommit utility, see Connecting to AWS CodeCommit repositories with rotating credentials in the AWS CodeCommit User Guide.
  • Amazon Keyspaces (for Apache Cassandra) access â€“ In a situation where you are unable to use users in IAM Identity Center, such as for testing purposes for Cassandra compatibility, you can use an IAM user with service-specific credentials to authenticate with Amazon Keyspaces. Users in IAM Identity Center are the people in your workforce who need access to your AWS accounts or to your cloud applications. You can also connect to Amazon Keyspaces using temporary credentials. For more information, see Using temporary credentials to connect to Amazon Keyspaces using an IAM role and the SigV4 plugin in the Amazon Keyspaces (for Apache Cassandra) Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use a strong root user password to help protect access
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you use a password that is strong and unique. Tools such as password managers with strong password generation algorithms can help you achieve these goals. AWS requires that your password meet the following conditions:

  • It must have a minimum of 8 characters and a maximum of 128 characters.
  • It must include a minimum of three of the following mix of character types: uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and ! @ # $ % ^ & * () <> [] {} | _+-= symbols.
  • It must not be identical to your AWS account name or email address.

For more information, see Change the password for the AWS account root user.

countermeasure.name: Use conditions in IAM policies to further restrict access
countermeasure.desc: You can specify conditions under which a policy statement is in effect. That way, you can grant access to actions and resources, but only if the access request meets specific conditions. For example, you can write a policy condition to specify that all requests must be sent using SSL. You can also use conditions to grant access to service actions, but only if they are used through a specific AWS service, such as AWS CloudFormation. IAM Access Analyzer analyzes the services and actions that your IAM roles use, and then generates a fine-grained policy that you can use. After you test each generated policy, you can deploy the policy to your production environment. This ensures that you grant only the required permissions to your workloads. usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Compromised root user credentials can lead to complete account takeover
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised root user credentials can lead to a complete account takeover and unauthorized access to all resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This can occur if an attacker gains knowledge of the root user's password through phishing, brute force attacks, or social engineering. Additionally, poor security practices like not enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) heighten the risk. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to every service and resource in the AWS environment, leading to data breaches, financial loss, and operational downtime. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sends a phishing email to the root user, tricking them into entering their credentials on a fake login page. Once the attacker gains those credentials, they log in to the AWS console and have unrestricted access to all resources, potentially deleting critical data and launching new instances at the victim's expense.

threat.name: Excessive permissions granted to users and roles can lead to unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Excessive permissions granted to users and roles can lead to unauthorized access and actions within the AWS environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal users with broad permissions, compromised user credentials, or roles with high levels of access. Attackers may exploit these to move laterally within the environment or escalate privileges.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data modification, infrastructure changes, financial loss, and potential regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal user with excessive privileges accidentally changes critical infrastructure settings, resulting in an outage. A compromised set of credentials is used to access sensitive data in S3 buckets which were granted broad read permissions, leading to a data breach.

threat.name: Unauthorized individuals exploiting recovery mechanisms can regain access to accounts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals exploiting recovery mechanisms can regain access to accounts even after credentials have been secured.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers who have previously compromised an account may exploit recovery processes such as password reset questions, email recovery, or multi-factor authentication reset bypasses to regain access.
Impacts
Repeated unauthorized access to accounts, leading to potential exfiltration of sensitive data, unauthorized changes to AWS resources, and long-term persistence within the environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker who previously had access to an account uses knowledge gained during the prior compromise to answer security questions accurately or bypass multi-factor authentication, allowing them to reset the password and regain access.

threat.name: Compromised account root user credentials can lead to unauthorized changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised root user credentials can lead to unauthorized changes to the overall account structure and permissions. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers who gain access to an organization's root user credentials through phishing, social engineering, or exploiting vulnerabilities. 
Impacts
Unauthorized changes to account structures and permissions, potentially causing data breaches, financial losses, and reputational damage. 
Example Attack Scenarios
Attackers use phishing emails to trick an employee into divulging root user credentials. Once obtained, the attackers make unauthorized changes to IAM policies, create new administrative users, and revoke access for legitimate users, leading to widespread disruption and data compromise.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Use of long-term credentials increases the risk of unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Use of long-term credentials increases the risk of unauthorized access due to their persistence and potential exposure. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors who may gain access to AWS IAM credentials through phishing, insecure storage, or exfiltration attack vectors. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access may lead to data breaches, unauthorized data manipulation, and potential financial losses for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an employee, obtaining long-term AWS IAM credentials. These credentials are then used to access sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions, going unnoticed for extended periods due to the persistent nature of the credentials.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring and unrestricted access can lead to undetected malicious activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of monitoring and unrestricted access can lead to undetected malicious activities and unauthorized access to resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers can exploit the lack of monitoring to engage in unauthorized or malicious activities without being detected. Additionally, users or services with unrestricted access may inadvertently or maliciously access sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to resources can result in data breaches, data loss, service disruptions, and significant financial and reputational damage. Undetected malicious activities can escalate over time, leading to more severe security incidents. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to an IAM user's credentials due to unrestricted access policies and leverages this to exfiltrate sensitive data without being detected due to inadequate monitoring.
2. An insider with excessive permissions intentionally deletes critical resources, causing service disruptions and data loss, which go unnoticed until significant damage has been done.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Restrict console access to trusted accounts using AWS Management Console Private Access
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Management Console Private Access is an advanced security feature to control access to the AWS Management Console. AWS Management Console Private Access is useful when you want to prevent users from signing in to unexpected AWS accounts from within your network. With this feature, you can limit access to the AWS Management Console only to a specified set of known AWS accounts when the traffic originates from within your network.

AWS Management Console Private Access is useful in scenarios when you want to limit access to the AWS Management Console from your network only to a specified set of known AWS accounts in your organization. By doing so, you can prevent users from signing in to unexpected AWS accounts from within your network. You can implement these controls using the AWS Management Console VPC endpoint policy. For more information, see Implementing service control policies and VPC endpoint policies.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege

threat.name: Unauthorized console access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized users gaining access to the AWS Management Console can lead to data breaches, unauthorized changes, and other malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external hackers, disgruntled employees, or individuals with accidentally disclosed credentials. Attack vectors might involve phishing, credential stuffing, or brute force attacks.
Impacts
Potential impacts include exposure of sensitive data, loss of data integrity, disruption of services, and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could phish legitimate users into revealing their AWS credentials, then use those credentials to access critical resources and steal confidential data. Alternatively, a malicious insider might use their access to delete or alter important files, disrupting business operations.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-266
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-266: Incorrect Privilege Assignment A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-500
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-500: Public Static Field Not Marked Final An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways. Public static variables can be read without an accessor and changed without a mutator by any classes in the application.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Enable audit logs and metrics
countermeasure.desc:
Thoroughly monitor your RDS instances by exporting database logs and OS metrics to CloudWatch Logs, and recording all management API activity via CloudTrail:

  1. Publish database logs to CloudWatch Logs

    • In the RDS console, navigate to Databases â†’ [your instance] â†’ Modify.
    • Under Log exports, select the general, slow query, and error logs and apply the change.

    • (CLI example):

      aws rds modify-db-instance \

       --db-instance-identifier mydb \

       --cloudwatch-logs-export-configuration '{"EnableLogTypes":["error","general","slowquery"]}' \

       --apply-immediately

    This streams each selected log into its own CloudWatch Logs group for real-time analysis and alerting DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.

  2. Enable Enhanced Monitoring
    • In the same Modify workflow, under Monitoring, toggle Enable Enhanced Monitoring.
    • Choose a granularity (e.g. 1 s or 15 s) and allow RDS to create or specify the rds-monitoring-role IAM role.
    • Enhanced Monitoring delivers OS-level metrics (CPU, memory, file I/O, etc.) into CloudWatch Logs for deeper visibility DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  3. Capture RDS API activity with CloudTrail
    • Ensure you have a CloudTrail trail that logs management events for all regions.
    • Confirm that Write and Read events for the rds.amazonaws.com service are included.
    • Use the CloudTrail console or Event history to search for RDS API calls (e.g., CreateDBInstance, ModifyDBInstance), capturing who did what and when DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.

References

  • Logging and monitoring in Amazon RDS (publishing logs & enhanced monitoring)
  • Monitoring Amazon RDS API calls in AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Protect all data at rest in Amazon RDS by leveraging AWS KMS keys (either the AWS-managed aws/rds key or your own customer-managed CMK) to perform AES-256 encryption:

  1. Enable encryption at instance creation
    • When creating a new DB instance (via Console, CLI, or CloudFormation), set Enable encryption to true.
    • In the Encryption section, choose either:
      • AWS managed key (aws/rds) for turnkey management.
      • Customer managed key (specify the KMS key ARN) if you require full control over key rotation and access policies.
    • CLI example:
    • aws rds create-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --engine mysql \
       --allocated-storage 20 \
       --storage-encrypted \
       --kms-key-id arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd-1234-efgh-5678
  2. Ensure all related resources inherit encryption
    • Automated backups, read replicas, and DB snapshots of an encrypted instance are automatically encrypted with the same KMS key.
    • If you restore from an encrypted snapshot into a new instance, specify the KMS key to maintain encryption.
  3. Manage and audit your keys
    • If using a customer-managed CMK, enable automatic key rotation in the KMS console to rotate the key annually.
    • Use IAM key policies and grants to restrict which principals and roles can use or manage the key.
    • Audit all key usage via AWS CloudTrail to monitor who accessed or decrypted your RDS data DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.

By enforcing AES-256 encryption with AWS KMSâ€“managed or customer-managed keys, you ensure that your RDS storage, backups, and replicas remain confidential, tamper-resistant, and compliant with encryption-at-rest requirements.

References

  • Amazon RDS encryption keys (AWS-managed vs. customer-managed)
  • Encryption best practices for Amazon RDS

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS connections
countermeasure.desc:
Encrypt every clientâ€“database session and forbid cleartext access by:

  1. Enforce TLS at the engine level
    • PostgreSQL: In your custom parameter group, set rds.force_ssl = 1 and apply it to your instances.
    • MySQL/MariaDB: In your parameter group, set require_secure_transport = ON.
    • SQL Server/Oracle: Use the RDS console or CLI to enable the â€œrequire SSLâ€ option in the instanceâ€™s security settings.
      This ensures the database itself will refuse non-TLS connections DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  2. Distribute and rotate the RDS CA certificates
    • Download the AWS RDS root CA bundle (rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem) from the AWS User Guide.
    • Provision it to your application servers (e.g. via S3, CI/CD pipeline, or configuration management) with appropriate file permissions.
  3. Configure client drivers to use SSL/TLS
    • JDBC (MySQL):
    • jdbc:mysql://mydb.xxxx.region.rds.amazonaws.com:3306/dbname \
       ?useSSL=true \
       &requireSSL=true \
       &verifyServerCertificate=true \
       &trustCertificateKeyStoreUrl=file:/path/to/rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem
    • psql (PostgreSQL):
    • psql "host=mydb.xxxx.region.rds.amazonaws.com port=5432 dbname=mydb \
       sslmode=verify-full \
       sslrootcert=/path/to/rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem"
    • Other drivers: Consult your driverâ€™s SSL/TLS configuration options and point them at the RDS CA bundle DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  4. Validate and disable fallback
    • Attempt a connection with SSL disabled (e.g. sslmode=disable or useSSL=false): it must fail.
    • Monitor your RDS instanceâ€™s connections via CloudWatch Metrics (e.g. DatabaseConnections) to confirm only TLS handshakes are occurring.

By enforcing engine-level TLS requirements, distributing AWS-provided certificates, and configuring every client to verify the serverâ€™s identity, you eliminate unencrypted endpoints and protect data in transit from eavesdropping and tampering.

References

  • Using SSL/TLS to encrypt a connection to a DB instance or cluster
  • Securing connections to RDS for PostgreSQL with SSL/TLS

countermeasure.name: Restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
Isolate your RDS databases from the public internet and lock down network access by:

  1. Use private subnets for RDS
    • Create or select a DB subnet group that contains only private subnets (no route to an Internet Gateway).
    • When launching or modifying the RDS instance, set Publicly Accessible to No and attach it to this DB subnet group DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  2. Configure security groups
    • Create a dedicated security group for your RDS instance.
    • Add inbound rules that permit only the necessary source CIDR ranges (e.g., your application serversâ€™ subnets or bastion host IP) on the database port (e.g., TCP 3306 for MySQL).
    • aws ec2 authorize-security-group-ingress \
       --group-id sg-0123456789abcdef0 \
       --protocol tcp \
       --port 3306 \
       --cidr 10.0.1.0/24
    • Do not allow wide-open access (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Keep outbound rules minimal (typically allow all or restrict to required management services).
  3. Enforce subnet-level rules with network ACLs
    • Associate a custom network ACL with your private subnets.
    • Define stateless rules that allow only the required traffic and deny everything else:
      • Inbound: Permit TCP on your DB port from your application subnet ranges.
      • Outbound: Permit established response traffic back to those same ranges.
      • Add a â€œdeny allâ€ rule with a higher rule number to block any other traffic.
    • This adds a second layer of defense at the subnet boundary DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.

By placing RDS in private subnets, using least-privilege security groups, and applying explicit network ACL rules, you ensure that only authorized hosts and ports can reach your database, reducing attack surface and improving overall network security.

References

  • Amazon VPC and Amazon RDS in a VPC
  • Control subnet traffic with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Rotate credentials regularly
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure your applications never embed static credentials by centralizing secret storage, automating rotation, and enforcing least-privilege access via IAM roles:

  1. Manage and rotate secrets in AWS Secrets Manager
    • Create a secret for your database credentials in Secrets Manager (e.g. RDS master user or application user).
    • Enable automatic rotation using the built-in RDS rotation Lambda or a custom rotation function. This updates both the secret and the database credentials on a schedule you define (e.g. every 30 days) DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
    • Grant your applicationâ€™s EC2 instance profile, ECS task role, or Lambda execution role the secretsmanager:GetSecretValue permission scoped to the secret ARN.
  2. Use SecureString parameters in Systems Manager Parameter Store
    • Store credentials as SecureString parameters encrypted by a KMS key.
    • Automate rotation by invoking a Lambda (via EventBridge) to generate new credentials, update the database, and overwrite the Parameter Store value.
    • Restrict access with an IAM policy granting only ssm:GetParameter (and kms:Decrypt on the KMS key) to the applicationâ€™s IAM role DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  3. Enforce IAM roleâ€“based access
    • Assign a dedicated IAM role to each application component (EC2, ECS, Lambda) that needs database access.
    • Use least-privilege policies that allow only the specific secrets or parameters required, avoiding broad wildcards.
    • Rotate application role credentials via AWS-managed mechanisms (e.g., EC2 Instance Metadata, IAM Roles for Service Accounts) so that no long-lived keys are stored in code or configuration.

By centralizing secrets in managed stores, automating credential rotation, and gating retrieval through narrowly scoped IAM roles, you dramatically reduce the risk of credential leakage and ensure seamless, secure database access.

References

  • Automatic rotation for database secrets in AWS Secrets Manager
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store overview

countermeasure.name: Use least-privilege IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that every IAM role or user interacting with your RDS environment has only the permissions they needâ€”and no moreâ€”by:

  1. Define minimal, role-specific policies
    • Identify each persona or workload (e.g., application read-only access, backup automation, monitoring, DBA).
    • Write IAM policies granting only the exact RDS (and related) actions required. For example, an application role might need only rds:Connect, rds:DescribeDBInstances, and secretsmanager:GetSecretValue on its credential secret.
    • Scope policies tightly using resource ARNs and, where possible, IAM policy conditions (e.g. source VPC, date/time).
  2. Attach policies to IAM roles
    • Use IAM roles (not long-lived credentials) for EC2, Lambda, ECS tasks, or any service needing RDS access.
    • Avoid embedding AWS credentials in code or environment variables.
  3. Regularly audit and refine permissions
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer to surface unused access and external sharing in your account. Review its findings and remove any permissions not in active use DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
    • Use the IAM consoleâ€™s Access Advisor (last-accessed information) to detect actions that havenâ€™t been invoked and tighten policies accordingly.
    • Schedule quarterly reviews of all RDS-related IAM roles and policies, revoking any excessive or stale privileges.

By rigorously applying least-privilege principles and leveraging AWS tools to detect and remove unused permissions, you minimize the blast radius of compromised credentials and adhere to security best practices.

References

  • AWS IAM Security Best Practices (least-privilege guidance)
  • AWS IAM Access Analyzer overview

countermeasure.name: Use multi-AZ and automated backups
countermeasure.desc:
Increase resilience and recoverability of your Amazon RDS databases by deploying across Availability Zones, retaining backups, and validating restores:

  1. Enable Multi-AZ deployments
    • When creating or modifying your DB instance, set Multi-AZ deployment to Yes (in the Console), or include:
    • aws rds modify-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --multi-az \
       --apply-immediately
    • This provisions a synchronous standby replica in a different AZ and configures automatic failover DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.
  2. Configure automated backups and snapshots
    • In the RDS Console under Backup retention, choose a retention period that meets your data retention policy (e.g. 7â€“35 days).
    • Ensure Enable automated backups is turned on; RDS will create daily snapshots and capture transaction logs for continuous backup.
    • (CLI example):
    • aws rds modify-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --backup-retention-period 14 \
       --apply-immediately
  3. Test point-in-time recovery (PITR) regularly
    • At least quarterly, perform a restore to a specific point in time:
    • aws rds restore-db-instance-to-point-in-time \
       --source-db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --target-db-instance-identifier mydb-pitr-test \
       --use-latest-restorable-time
    • Validate that the restored instance comes online, that data reflects the intended timestamp, and then clean up the test instance. This confirms your backups and logs are functioning correctly DocumentaciÃ³n de AWS.

By combining Multi-AZ high availability, automated backups with transaction-log retention, and routine PITR drills, you ensure rapid failover, data durability, and verified recovery processes.

References

  • Configuring and managing a Multi-AZ deployment for Amazon RDS
  • Backing up and restoring your Amazon RDS DB instance

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insufficient backup and recovery
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient backup and recovery occurs when RDS instances lack properly configured automated snapshots, pointâ€inâ€time restore settings, or cross-region replication. Without reliable backups, data loss and extended outages become unavoidable after failures or deletions.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, and ransomware operators.
  • Attack Vectors: Misconfigured or disabled automated snapshots; failure to enable Multi-AZ or read-replica backups; absence of cross-region snapshot copy.

Impacts

  • Data Loss: Irrecoverable deletion or corruption of databases.
  • Extended Downtime: Prolonged recovery windows damaging SLAs and productivity.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of retention policies and data-protection regulations.
  • Financial Costs: Emergency restore efforts and potential penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental Deletion: A DBA drops a critical table; no snapshots exist, making recovery impossible.
  2. Ransomware Wipe: Malware gains write access and corrupts the primary DB; without recent backups, data cannot be restored.
  3. Region Outage: A zonal outage destroys the sole RDS instance and its local backups; lack of cross-region copies prevents failover.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured IAM policies for RDSâ€”either overly permissive or improperly restrictiveâ€”can let unauthorized actors perform sensitive database operations or prevent legitimate backups and restores.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM roles, negligent admins
  • Vectors: Wildcard actions (rds:* on *), overly broad principals, conflicting allow/deny rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized data access, modification, or deletion
  • Data exfiltration or corruption
  • Failed backups/restores and extended downtime
  • Compliance violations (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Wildcard Privilege Abuse: An attacker with a compromised role granted rds:* drops production tables and spins up malicious instances.
  2. Public Snapshot Exposure: A service account shares DB snapshots publicly because its IAM policy wasnâ€™t scoped to the account.
  3. Backup Failure: A deny rule blocks the rds:CreateDBSnapshot action, causing automated backups to fail during an outage.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data transmission occurs when RDS database trafficâ€”queries, results, replication streams, or backupsâ€”is sent over plaintext channels (e.g., without TLS), allowing anyone intercepting the network to read or tamper with the data in flight.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, MITM attackers, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Connecting to the RDS endpoint over non-TLS ports.
    • Forcing downgrade from TLS to plaintext via misconfigured clients.
    • Intercepting replication or backup traffic on unencrypted channels (e.g. S3 sync without HTTPS).

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive records (PII, credentials, financial data) can be harvested.
  • Data Tampering: In-flight modification of queries or results can corrupt or redirect data.
  • Session Hijacking: Database session tokens or temporary credentials captured to impersonate applications.
  • Compliance Violations: Transmitting regulated data without encryption breaches standards like PCI DSS, HIPAA, or GDPR.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Client Sniffing: An application connects to RDS over port 3306 without TLS; an attacker on the same network captures SQL traffic and extracts user passwords.
  2. Replication Interception: A read-replica in another region pulls data over an unencrypted channel, and a MITM alters replication events to inject malicious records.
  3. Backup Sync Eavesdrop: Automated backups are pushed to S3 over HTTP; a compromised network node intercepts the transfer and harvests raw database snapshots.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data at rest occurs when RDS storage volumesâ€”including automated snapshots, read replicas, and backupsâ€”are not encrypted, leaving all database contents accessible in cleartext.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers who gain storage access, and third-party service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM roles or credentials used to download unencrypted snapshots.
    • Unauthorized copying of EBS snapshots or S3-stored backups.
    • Insider misuse of snapshot export or share features to obtain raw data.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive PII, credentials, and business data are readable if storage or backups are exfiltrated.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of mandates like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI DSS that require encryption at rest.
  • Increased Breach Risk: Easy lateral movement or forensic analysis for attackers who obtain raw storage artifacts.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Snapshot Theft: An attacker compromises an IAM user with permission to copy RDS snapshots, downloads an unencrypted snapshot to S3, and extracts customer records offline.
  2. EBS Volume Access: A malicious admin detaches the underlying unencrypted EBS volume from an RDS instance, attaches it to another host, and mounts it to read all data files directly.
  3. Backup Export Abuse: A disgruntled insider exports automated backups to an external account; since no encryption key is required, they can sieve through sensitive financial or health data at will.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.001 - Credentials In Files

threat.name: Excessive network exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Excessive network exposure occurs when RDS instances are reachable from broader network ranges than necessaryâ€”such as being publicly accessible or sitting in overly permissive security groupsâ€”enabling attackers to connect directly to the database.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, and compromised EC2 instances.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Publicly accessible RDS endpoints (Publicly Accessible = yes).
    • Security groups allowing 0.0.0.0/0 or wide CIDR on port 3306/5432.
    • Missing VPC peering restrictions or network ACLs, permitting lateral movement.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers probe and exploit database vulnerabilities.
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive records.
  • Service Disruption: DDoS or brute-force attacks degrade performance.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of network segmentation requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Endpoint Abuse: A database left â€œpublicly accessibleâ€ is discovered by an internet scanner; attacker uses default credentials to dump tables.
  2. Broad SG Rules: A security group opens port 5432 to all IPs; an attacker scripts login attempts until they compromise a privileged account.
  3. Lateral Pivoting: A compromised EC2 in the same VPC but different subnet connects to RDS using permissive network ACLs, then escalates privileges via SQL injection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When RDS instances lack adequate logging (e.g., disabled audit, error, or slow-query logs) and monitoring (e.g., missing CloudWatch alarms), malicious or accidental activity goes unnoticed, undermining detection, response, and forensic capabilities.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and automated malware.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting SQL injection or compromised credentials to modify or exfiltrate data without leaving audit trails.
    • Triggering performance-degrading queries (e.g., Cartesian joins) that go unflagged.
    • Misusing administrative APIs (e.g., snapshot deletion) with no alerting or logs.

Impacts

  • Delayed Detection: Intrusions or misconfigurations persist longer, increasing damage.
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Investigations canâ€™t reconstruct events, hindering root-cause analysis.
  • Compliance Failures: Absence of required audit logs breaches standards like PCI DSS or GDPR.
  • Prolonged Outages or Data Loss: Undetected errors or malicious changes lead to extended downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Silent Data Exfiltration: An attacker uses stolen credentials to dump sensitive tables; with audit logging off, no trail exists, delaying discovery for weeks.
  2. Undetected Configuration Change: A rogue insider disables automated backups via the API; without CloudWatch alarms or API-call logs, the change isnâ€™t spotted until itâ€™s too late.
  3. Stealthy Performance Attack: Malware issues heavy, slow queries that degrade database performance; absent slow-query logs and alarms, the performance drop is attributed to normal load until the service fails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1070.001 - Clear Windows Event Logs

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Weak credential management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak credential management occurs when database credentialsâ€”such as usernames, passwords, or IAM authentication tokensâ€”are handled insecurely (e.g. hard-coded, stored in plaintext, or not rotated), making them easy to discover or reuse.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious outsiders, compromised automation tools, and negligent insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Leaking credentials in source code repositories or container images.
    • Retrieving IAM-based database tokens from instance metadata with overly broad role permissions.
    • Exploiting exposed parameters in unencrypted Parameter Store or Secrets Manager entries.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers use stolen credentials to connect directly to the database.
  • Data Breach: Confidential records can be read, modified, or deleted.
  • Privilege Escalation: Compromised credentials may grant elevated privileges or access to other services.
  • Operational Disruption: Credential misuse can lead to denial of service or forced credential rotation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Code Commit Leak: A developer inadvertently commits db_password in application.properties to GitHub; attackers clone the repo and authenticate to the RDS instance.
  2. Metadata API Abuse: An EC2 instance role with rds-db:connect permission is compromised; an attacker queries the metadata endpoint for IAM tokens and accesses the database.
  3. Unencrypted Secret Retrieval: Credentials stored in plain-text in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store are retrieved by any user with read permissions, allowing unauthorized database connections.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply row-level security in Redshift
countermeasure.desc:
To implement row-level security in Amazon Redshift, follow these steps to ensure that only authorized users can view or modify specific rows of data:

  1. Create and Configure IAM Roles and Policies:
    First, create IAM roles and policies that define the specific permissions required for different user groups. These policies should restrict access based on the roles assigned to users. For detailed instructions, refer to the IAM user management documentation in Redshift: Managing IAM Roles and Permissions.
  2. Define Row-Level Security Policies:
    Utilize Redshift's built-in row-level security feature to create and enforce security predicates that specify which rows each user or group can access. Define these policies using SQL expressions that filter rows based on user roles or attributes. For more information, see the row-level security documentation: Implementing Row-Level Security.
  3. Apply Security Policies to Tables:
    After defining the security policies, apply them to the relevant tables or views within your Redshift cluster. This ensures that the row-level security measures are active and enforce the defined access controls for every query executed.
  4. Test and Validate Security Configurations:
    Thoroughly test the implemented row-level security policies using different user accounts to ensure they work as intended. Confirm that authorized users can access their permitted rows while unauthorized access is rejected.

By following these steps, you can effectively control user access at the row level in Amazon Redshift, enhancing your data security and compliance posture.

countermeasure.name: Configure Redshift cluster access using IAM roles
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access control to your Amazon Redshift clusters is crucial for ensuring that only authorized entities can access your data. Using AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles is an effective way to achieve this. Below is a step-by-step guide on how to implement IAM roles to restrict access:

Steps to Implement IAM Roles

  1. Create an IAM Role:
    • Navigate to the IAM Console.
    • Select Roles from the navigation pane and click on Create Role.
    • Choose the type of trusted entity: Usually, this would be "AWS service" (e.g., Redshift).
    • Attach the appropriate policy that allows access to your Redshift resources. AWS provides pre-defined policies that you can use, or you can create a custom policy. Reference: IAM Policies for Redshift.
    • Complete the role creation process by reviewing and providing a name for the role.
  2. Attach IAM Role to the Redshift Cluster:
    • Go to the Redshift Console.
    • Select the cluster you want to configure.
    • In the cluster details, go to the Properties tab.
    • Under Cluster Permissions, click on Manage IAM roles.
    • Add the created IAM role and save the changes.
  3. Verify Permissions:
    • Ensure that the policies attached to the IAM role are correctly configured and provide the necessary permissions for tasks that authorized entities need to perform.
    • Use the IAM Policy Simulator to test the permissions.

By following these steps, you can effectively restrict access to your Amazon Redshift clusters to authorized entities only, enhancing your data security. For more details, refer to the official Amazon documentation: Managing Redshift User Access.

countermeasure.name: Disable public accessibility for Redshift clusters
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Redshift clusters and prevent unauthorized access, it is vital to ensure that these clusters are not publicly accessible. Disabling the public accessibility setting ensures that your Redshift clusters are only accessible from within your VPC, mitigating the risk of exposure to the public internet and potential security breaches.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Open the Amazon Redshift console.
  3. In the navigation pane, choose Clusters.
  4. Select the cluster that you want to modify.
  5. Choose the Properties tab.
  6. Under the Network and security settings, find the Publicly accessible field.
  7. Click on the Edit button and change the setting to No.
  8. Click on the Save changes button to apply the new settings.

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the official documentation: Configuring Security Settings for Amazon Redshift.

References

  • Amazon Redshift Management Guide: Managing Redshift Users and Permissions
  • Amazon Redshift Security Settings

countermeasure.name: Enable audit logging in Redshift
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling audit logging in Amazon Redshift is an essential security measure to enhance the visibility of SQL operations, connections, and user activities. Activating this feature helps in detecting and preventing potential data exfiltration attempts. Below is a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer to implement this control:

Steps to Activate Audit Logging:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon Redshift console.
  2. In the navigation pane, choose Clusters.
  3. Select the cluster you want to enable audit logging for.
  4. Choose the Properties tab for the selected cluster.
  5. In the Database configurations section, locate the Audit logging configuration.
  6. Click on the Edit button and turn on audit logging by selecting the Enable checkbox.
  7. Specify the S3 bucket where the log files will be stored. Ensure this S3 bucket has the necessary permissions for the Redshift cluster to write logs to it. For more details on required permissions, refer to the official AWS Redshift audit logging documentation.
  8. Choose Save changes to activate audit logging for the selected cluster.

References:

For detailed security guidelines and additional options for managing users and permissions, refer to the Amazon Redshift security documentation: AWS Redshift User Management.

For further information on audit logging in Amazon Redshift, consult the audit logging documentation: Amazon Redshift Audit Logging.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest in Redshift
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing data encryption in Amazon Redshift ensures that your data is securely encrypted both at rest and in-transit, which protects your sensitive information from unauthorized access. Follow these steps to enable encryption for your Amazon Redshift cluster:

  1. Enable Encryption on Cluster Creation: When creating a new Amazon Redshift cluster, select the "Enable encryption" option. This can be done through the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or the Amazon Redshift API. Refer to the AWS documentation for specific instructions.
  2. Use AWS KMS for Key Management: Amazon Redshift utilizes the AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for managing encryption keys. You can either have AWS manage the keys for you or create and manage your own customer-managed keys (CMKs). Detailed guidance is available in the official documentation.
  3. Encrypt Existing Clusters: To encrypt an existing cluster, create a snapshot, enable encryption on the snapshot, and then restore the snapshot to a new encrypted cluster. Instructions can be found here.
  4. Data in Transit: Ensure that your data is also encrypted in-transit by configuring your connections to use SSL/TLS. You can find SSL configuration steps in the official guidelines.

By following the steps outlined above, you can leverage Amazon Redshift's built-in encryption capabilities to protect your data at rest, ensuring compliance with security best practices and regulatory requirements.

countermeasure.name: Enforce VPC-based isolation of Redshift clusters
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure network isolation and enhanced control over your Amazon Redshift clusters, place them within an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). By doing so, you gain the ability to manage inbound and outbound traffic through security groups and network access control lists (ACLs), reducing the risk of unauthorized access and interception.

Implementation Steps

  1. Create a VPC: In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the VPC Dashboard and create a new VPC as per your network design requirements.
  2. Configure Subnets: Design and configure public and private subnets within the VPC to control access to resources as needed.
  3. Modify Redshift Cluster Configuration: When launching a new Redshift cluster, specify the created VPC and appropriate subnets under the 'Network and security settings' option.
  4. Set Up Security Groups: Attach security groups to your Redshift cluster to define rules that control the traffic to your cluster.
  5. Configure Network ACLs: Use network ACLs to provide an additional layer of stateless filtering of traffic entering and leaving a subnet.
  6. Verify Connectivity: Test the connections to ensure that data flow and security configurations are functioning correctly in your VPC setup.

For detailed steps and best practices on securing your Amazon Redshift cluster within a VPC, refer to the AWS Redshift Cluster Management Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use security groups to control Redshift cluster access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Redshift clusters, you should configure security groups to allow inbound traffic only from trusted IP addresses or VPCs. This minimizes the attack surface by ensuring that only authorized entities can access your Redshift clusters.

Steps to Configure Security Groups

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. In the navigation pane, under Redshift, choose Clusters.
  3. Select the Redshift cluster for which you want to configure the security group.
  4. Under the Cluster Properties section, find the Network and Security settings.
  5. Click on the security group associated with your Redshift cluster to edit its settings.
  6. In the Inbound tab, create rules that specify the trusted IP addresses or VPCs from which traffic is allowed. For example, you can add inbound rules to allow traffic from a specific IP address range (CIDR block) or from a specific VPC security group.
  7. Click Save to apply the security group updates.

Best Practices

  • Regularly review and update your security group rules to ensure they reflect your current security requirements.
  • Use the principle of least privilege by allowing the minimum necessary access to your Redshift clusters.
  • Consider automating the monitoring and management of your security groups for continuous compliance.

For more detailed information, refer to the official AWS Redshift Cluster Security Groups documentation.

Also, review the AWS Redshift User Management guide for additional security best practices.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Redshift clusters
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls can result in unauthorized users gaining access to Redshift clusters, potentially leading to significant data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers exploiting vulnerabilities, weak password policies, and misconfigured access control lists.
Impacts
Sensitive data exposure, data manipulation, loss of data integrity, financial losses, regulatory fines, and damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker bypasses weak access controls to extract sensitive financial data from the Redshift cluster, or a disgruntled employee exploits insufficient access restrictions to alter data tables, leading to misinformation and operational disruption.

threat.name: Data exfiltration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper data protection mechanisms, sensitive data within Redshift clusters could be exfiltrated by malicious actors.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, malicious insiders, or compromised accounts that can exploit vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in Redshift clusters. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access through weak authentication mechanisms, exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, or leveraging poorly configured permissions.
Impacts
The impacts of such threats include data breaches resulting in the loss or exposure of sensitive information, legal and regulatory consequences, financial losses, reputational damage, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external hacker exploits a vulnerability in Redshift's security settings to gain unauthorized access to the cluster, extracting sensitive customer data. In another scenario, a malicious insider with legitimate credentials downloads confidential business information from the Redshift cluster and sells it to a competitor.

threat.name: Exposed Redshift cluster endpoints
threat.desc:
General threat description
Exposed Redshift cluster endpoints can lead to unauthorized access and potential exploitation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, including external attackers and malicious insiders, can exploit exposed endpoints to gain access to Redshift clusters. Attack vectors include scanning for open ports and leveraging known vulnerabilities in misconfigured Redshift settings.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized data manipulation, potential service disruptions, and financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an exposed Redshift endpoint through network scanning, then uses default credentials or brute-force techniques to gain access, leading to data theft or manipulation. Another scenario involves an insider exploiting misconfigured security groups to access restricted data, resulting in data leakage and compliance violations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modifications
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured user permissions can result in unauthorized access and potentially harmful modifications to data stored in the Redshift cluster.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or internal employees with inadequate access restrictions could exploit these improper user permissions. Attack vectors may include exploiting vulnerable IAM roles, inheritance of excessive privileges, or bypassing access controls.
Impacts
Unauthorized users could modify, delete, or tamper with sensitive data, leading to data breaches, loss of data integrity, and compliance violations. This could result in financial loss, reputational damage, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
- An internal employee inherits permissions that allow modification of critical financial data, leading to fraudulent activities.
- A hacker exploits weak IAM roles to gain administrative control over the Redshift cluster, allowing them to alter or delete essential business data.
- An external contractor is granted overly broad permissions, enabling them to access and modify sensitive customer information inappropriately.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1647 - Plist File Modification

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693

This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption â€“ All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption â€“ Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineâ€”regular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.desc:

Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.
