countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnâ€™t record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnâ€™t support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youâ€™ve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wonâ€™t be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Automate secure configuration management
countermeasure.desc:
Eliminate manual errors and detect drift by managing every Direct Connect objectâ€”connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associationsâ€”through vetted infrastructure-as-code (IaC) pipelines and continuous compliance checks:

  1. define configurations in IaC
    • Use AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or AWS CDK modules that encapsulate approved settings (BGP ASN ranges, VLAN IDs, Jumbo Frames, SiteLink = false).
    • Parameterize only what needs to vary (Region, speed); hard-code security defaults (e.g., enableSiteLink: false, mtu: 9001).
  2. enforce change control
    • Protect the IaC repo with branch protection, mandatory code-review, and automated security linting (cfn-nag, tfsec).
    • Require all Direct Connect changes to flow through the pipeline; block console or ad-hoc CLI edits with an Organizations SCP denying directconnect:* when aws:CalledViaLast â‰  cloudformation.amazonaws.com or your CI role.
  3. continuous drift detection
    • Turn on AWS Config rule directconnect-connection-config-check (custom) that compares live attributes to the IaC source of truth; mark resources NON_COMPLIANT on mismatch.
    • Trigger an EventBridge rule that opens a ticket or auto-reverts drift via an SSM automation document.
  4. version and audit
    • Tag every Direct Connect resource with the Git commit hash that provisioned it (IaCCommit=<sha>).
    • Store pipeline logs and change sets in an immutable S3 bucket for forensic review.

Automated, declarative management guarantees consistent security baselines, accelerates approved changes, and surfaces unauthorized modifications within minutes.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?
  • What Is AWS Config?

countermeasure.name: Enforce IAM identity-based policies for AWS Direct Connect
countermeasure.desc:
Create narrowly scoped IAM policies (and, if you use AWS Organizations, complementary SCPs) so that only approved â€œnetwork-adminâ€ roles can perform Direct Connect management actionsâ€”such as CreateConnection, AllocateHostedConnection, ConfirmPrivateVirtualInterface, or DeleteLag.

  • Author purpose-built roles â€“ give each network-engineering or automation role a custom policy that allows only the Direct Connect APIs it truly needs and only in approved Regions or on resources tagged Environment=prod. Example snippet:
  • {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": [
       "directconnect:CreateConnection",
       "directconnect:DeleteConnection",
       "directconnect:Describe*"
     ],
     "Resource": "*",
     "Condition": {
       "StringEquals": { "aws:RequestedRegion": [ "us-east-1", "eu-west-1" ] },
       "ForAllValues:StringEquals": { "aws:ResourceTag/NetworkOwner": "net-ops" }
     }
    }
  • Block everyone else â€“ attach an SCP that denies directconnect:* unless the principal ARN matches the network-admin roles or the AWS SSO group you designate.
  • Require MFA for sensitive calls â€“ add an IAM condition BoolIfExists/aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent : true so console users must present MFA when modifying connections or virtual interfaces.
  • Monitor and audit â€“ stream CloudTrail events that match directconnect:* to CloudWatch Logs and set an EventBridge rule to alert on any caller outside your allow-list.
  • Review quarterly â€“ export IAM Access Analyzer â€œlast usedâ€ data and remove unused Direct Connect permissions; update Region and tag conditions as your footprint changes.

Enforcing identity-based, least-privilege policies prevents unauthorized creation, deletion, or tampering of Direct Connect links that could disrupt hybrid connectivity.

References

  • What is AWS Direct Connect?

countermeasure.name: Implement BGP hijacking protections
countermeasure.desc:
Protect Direct Connect virtual interfaces from BGP hijacking and route leaks by configuring both ends of the peering sessionâ€”your on-prem router and AWSâ€”to accept only authenticated, pre-agreed prefixes and AS paths:

  1. enable BGP MD5 authentication
    • When you create or update the private or transit virtual interface, specify a BGP MD5 key (Amazon console â†’ Add BGP password).
    • Configure the matching password <secret> on your customer router so unauthenticated sessions are rejected.
  2. advertise and accept explicit prefix lists
    • On your router, use a prefix-list / route-map that only advertises the exact CIDR blocks you own (no more-specifics, no 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Apply an inbound filter that accepts only the AWS-announced RFC 1918 ranges (or any public space you expect) to prevent a poisoned route table.
  3. set max-prefix & as-path filters
    • neighbor <aws-peering-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5â€”pick N slightly above the number of prefixes you legitimately expect (e.g., 5 % head-room).
    • Deny inbound prefixes whose AS_PATH is not exactly AS16509 (AWS) or the sequence you anticipate for a hosted connection.
  4. enable BFD and low hold timers
    • Turn on Bidirectional Forwarding Detection (BFD) and set aggressive timers (e.g., 300 ms, 3 multiplier) so hijacked or flapping sessions drop quickly.
    • If your device lacks BFD, reduce BGP keep-alive/hold timers (30 / 90 s) instead of the defaults.
  5. monitor and alert
    • Stream Direct Connect BGP state change and RouteChange CloudWatch metrics; alarm on BGPPeerDown, MaxPrefixesExceeded, or unexpected ASN/path events.
    • Log all BGP syslog messages on the customer router to a SIEM and detect new or more-specific routes instantly.
  6. review quarterly
    • Compare advertised prefixes against your IPAM source of truth; prune any stale routes.
    • Rotate the BGP MD5 key when staff leave or devices are replaced.

These layered controlsâ€”authentication, strict prefix/as-path filtering, and rapid failure detectionâ€”greatly reduce the chance that an attacker can hijack your Direct Connect traffic or inject malicious routes.

References

  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Monitor and safeguard BGP routes
countermeasure.desc:
Continuously watch every Direct Connect BGP session and automatically flagâ€”or shut downâ€”any route change that could steer traffic to an unexpected destination.

  1. Stream BGP telemetry to CloudWatch
    • Enable the Direct Connect metrics BgpPeerState, BgpRouteFlapDampening, and BGPMaxPrefixesExceeded.
    • Create CloudWatch alarms that fire when a peer drops (BgpPeerState = 3), the route count jumps beyond the configured max-prefix value, or flapping exceeds a defined threshold.
  2. Log all route advertisements
    • On the customer router, export BGP UPDATE messages to a syslog or NetFlow collector; forward to your SIEM for real-time correlation.
    • Retain logs for at least 90 days so you can trace when and how a suspicious prefix entered the table.
  3. Detect drift with AWS Config & EventBridge
    • Deploy a custom AWS Config rule that compares the live list of accepted/advertised prefixes against your approved prefix list in IPAM.
    • When Config marks a resource NON_COMPLIANT, trigger an EventBridge rule that pages on-call staff andâ€”optionallyâ€”runs an SSM Automation document to disable the virtual interface until reviewed.
  4. Implement route sanity checks
    • Use the routerâ€™s prefix-list + route-map to drop any prefix longer than /24 or outside your owned CIDR blocks.
    • Set neighbor <peer-ip> maximum-prefix <N> restart 5 to halt a session that suddenly advertises too many routes.
  5. Visualise and review
    • Build a CloudWatch dashboard that shows current prefix count, peer state, and alarm status for every virtual interface.
    • Review logs and metrics weekly; investigate any new ASN in the AS-PATH or unexplained rise in prefix count.

Proactive monitoring combined with automatic drift detection stops hijacked, leaked, or mis-typed routes before they impact production traffic.

References

  • Monitoring Direct Connect BGP sessions with CloudWatch metrics
  • AWS Direct Connect routing policies and BGP communities

countermeasure.name: Regularly audit Direct Connect configurations
countermeasure.desc:
At least once per quarterâ€”and after every network changeâ€”generate and review a complete inventory of Direct Connect resources (connections, LAGs, virtual interfaces, gateway associations, route filters, and BGP settings). Compare the live state against your infrastructure-as-code definitions and security baseline, then remediate drift immediately.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the snapshot
    • Run aws directconnect describe-* commands (or Terraform / CloudFormation drift-detect) from a scheduled pipeline; export JSON to an S3 bucket versioned for audit.
  2. Evaluate with AWS Config & Security Hub
    • Enable custom and managed Config rulesâ€”for example, flag connections without BGP MD5 keys or VIFs without route filters. Send findings to Security Hub so they appear on your compliance dashboard.
  3. Cross-check critical attributes
    • Verify port speed, LOA expiry, VLAN IDs, SiteLink status, BGP ASN, maximum-prefix limits, and MD5 keys against your approved standards document or IPAM system.
  4. Document and remediate
    • Publish an audit report listing compliant items, drift, and required fixes. Track remediation tasks in your ticket system and confirm closure before the next audit cycle.

Regular, tool-driven audits prevent silent mis-configurations that could break redundancy, expose routes, or violate compliance requirements.

References

  • Evaluating Resources with AWS Config Rules

countermeasure.name: Use PFS-supported cipher suites
countermeasure.desc:
Whether youâ€™re calling the AWS APIs that manage Direct Connect or encrypting application payloads that traverse the circuit (for example, TLS to private NLBs or HTTPS to AWS service endpoints), configure the TLS stack so it negotiates only cipher suites that provide Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)â€”that is, suites that use an ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange such as ECDHE or DHE.

Implementation guidance

  1. restrict the client cipher list
    • On routers, firewalls, and application servers that initiate TLS sessions over Direct Connect, remove all static-key suites (RSA key exchange) and legacy ciphers (3DES, RC4).
    • Keep the list to modern suites such as TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, or (preferably) TLS 1.3 defaults.
  2. enforce on inbound endpoints
    • For load balancers and APIs hosted in AWS, select an ELB security policy that requires TLS 1.2/1.3 with PFS (for example ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06).
    • Reject client hellos that offer only non-PFS suites.
  3. verify with automated scans
    • Use openssl s_client -cipher 'aNULL' -connect host:443 and expect no handshake.
    • Schedule weekly or monthly scans (SSLLabs, AWS Inspector network assessments) to confirm no regressions.
  4. monitor for legacy fall-back
    • Enable CloudTrail data-events for ELB and look for TLSNegotiationError.
    • Set CloudWatch alarms on a spike in cipher-mismatch metricsâ€”an early sign that a client or server reverted to weak crypto.

PFS ensures that, even if a long-term private key is later compromised, past TLS sessions cannot be decryptedâ€”an essential property for protecting high-value traffic flowing over dedicated circuits like AWS Direct Connect.

References

  • Create an HTTPS listener for your Application Load Balancer

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data interception involves unauthorized parties gaining access to data as it is being transmitted over the network. This threat compromises the confidentiality and integrity of data sent via AWS Direct Connect, potentially leading to data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and state-sponsored actors. Attack vectors include man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network devices, and physical tapping of communication lines.

Impacts

Data interception can result in confidentiality breaches, data integrity compromise, operational disruption, reputational damage, and financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts communication between an on-premises network and AWS by positioning themselves between the endpoints, allowing them to eavesdrop or inject malicious data into the communication stream.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to individuals gaining access to AWS Direct Connect resources without proper authorization. This can occur due to weak access controls, compromised credentials, or configuration errors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized manipulation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and attackers exploiting compromised credentials. Attack vectors include stolen or weak passwords, misconfigured IAM policies, and exploitation of insufficiently restricted network access.

Impacts

Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized changes to configurations, financial loss, and reputational damage. It compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the AWS environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker gains access to AWS Direct Connect resources by exploiting weak or stolen credentials, allowing them to view or manipulate sensitive data. Another scenario involves a misconfigured IAM policy that inadvertently grants excessive permissions to a user, leading to unauthorized actions within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure configuration involves improper setup of AWS Direct Connect resources, leading to potential vulnerabilities. Misconfigurations can result from errors in security settings, inadequate access controls, or failure to follow best practices, exposing the infrastructure to various threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include system administrators, attackers exploiting configuration errors, and automated tools scanning for vulnerabilities. Attack vectors include misconfigured access controls, incorrect security group settings, and failure to apply updates or patches.

Impacts

Insecure configurations can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exploitation of vulnerable systems. These issues can compromise the security and integrity of data and services.

Example Attack Scenarios

An administrator mistakenly configures overly permissive access controls, allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive data through AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves outdated security settings that an attacker exploits to gain unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and service disruptions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: BGP hijacking
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

BGP hijacking involves malicious actors rerouting internet traffic by corrupting the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) routing tables. This allows attackers to intercept, monitor, or manipulate data intended for legitimate network paths, potentially impacting AWS Direct Connect's communication routes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main threat agents include cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and rogue network operators. Attack vectors involve manipulating BGP announcements to falsely advertise ownership of IP prefixes, causing traffic to be misrouted through the attackerâ€™s network.

Impacts

BGP hijacking can lead to data interception, traffic analysis, disruption of services, loss of data integrity, and potential data breaches. It can cause significant operational disruptions and loss of trust in network security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker corrupts BGP routing tables to divert traffic from a corporate network to their own servers, allowing them to capture sensitive information transmitted via AWS Direct Connect. Another scenario involves an attacker using a compromised or rogue router to announce false BGP routes, disrupting service availability and causing a loss of connectivity for critical applications.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Hereâ€™s a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, itâ€™s crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizationâ€™s reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-539
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

weakness.name: CWE-663
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-663: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

countermeasure.name: Conduct frequent configuration reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly review system and server configurations to ensure that security settings are properly implemented and sensitive data is not exposed. Conducting configuration reviews helps identify misconfigurations, weak access controls, and other vulnerabilities that could lead to unauthorized access or data leakage.

Implementation Steps:

Define Configuration Review Scope:

  • Include critical configurations such as access controls, encryption settings, user permissions, and network configurations in the review.
  • Ensure compliance with security best practices and regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS).

Review Access Controls:

  • Verify that only authorized users have access to sensitive data and critical systems.
  • Ensure that default credentials and unnecessary accounts are removed or disabled.

Check Data Protection Settings:

  • Ensure that sensitive data is encrypted both in transit (using TLS) and at rest (using strong encryption algorithms like AES).
  • Review file permissions to ensure that sensitive files are not accessible to unauthorized users.

Examine Security Policies and Rules:

  • Regularly audit security policies, firewall rules, and network configurations to ensure they are up to date and provide the necessary protection.
  • Verify that logging and monitoring systems are correctly configured to detect any suspicious activity.

Document and Act on Findings:

  • Document all findings from the configuration reviews and prioritize actions to address non-compliant configurations or identified vulnerabilities.
  • Implement changes and re-test configurations to ensure they align with security standards.

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Perform configuration reviews quarterly or after significant changes to the environment (e.g., updates, new deployments).
  • Use automated tools to assist with the review process, making it more efficient and thorough.

By conducting frequent configuration reviews, organizations can ensure that security settings are correct, minimizing the risk of exposure and ensuring that sensitive data remains protected.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

countermeasure.name: Enforce role-based access controls and multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement role-based access controls (RBAC), multi-factor authentication (MFA), and the principle of least privilege to minimize unauthorized access to internal systems and resources. By ensuring that only authorized personnel have access to necessary data and systems, these measures reduce the risk of accidental or intentional misuse of sensitive information and limit exposure to attacks.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define roles within your organization and assign permissions based on job responsibilities. Ensure that each user has access only to the resources necessary for their role.
  • Regularly review and update roles to reflect any changes in job functions or responsibilities.

Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • Require MFA for all users accessing critical systems or sensitive data. This ensures that even if credentials are compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.
  • Use authentication methods like mobile apps, hardware tokens, or biometrics alongside passwords.

Enforce the Principle of Least Privilege:

  • Ensure that users, systems, and applications have the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.
  • Review and adjust access levels periodically to ensure they remain aligned with users' current roles.

Audit and Review Access Logs:

  • Regularly audit access logs to ensure that access controls are being properly enforced and that no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Implement alerts to notify administrators of suspicious or anomalous access attempts.

Educate and Train Users:

  • Provide ongoing training to users on secure access practices, including how to use MFA and why least privilege is important.
  • Educate users about the risks of privilege escalation and how to securely manage their credentials.

By enforcing these access control measures, developers and DevOps engineers can reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that only the appropriate personnel can access sensitive resources.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Access Control

countermeasure.name: Ensure server software is up-to-date with security patches
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update all server software, including operating systems and applications, with the latest security patches. Keeping software up-to-date reduces the risk of exploitation due to known vulnerabilities. Establish a patch management process to ensure timely updates and minimize exposure to security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Establish Patch Management Process:

  • Develop a formal patch management policy that includes patch assessment, approval, and deployment procedures.
  • Prioritize patches based on their severity and impact on server security.

Automate Patching for Critical Systems:

  • Use automation tools to deploy critical patches as soon as they are available to minimize the window of vulnerability.
  • Ensure that automatic updates are enabled for operating systems and essential applications.

Test Patches in a Staging Environment:

  • Before applying patches to production systems, test them in a staging environment to ensure they do not cause system instability or conflicts with other software.

Regularly Review Security Bulletins:

  • Subscribe to security mailing lists, such as those from software vendors and organizations like CVE or NIST, to stay informed about the latest vulnerabilities and patches.
  • Monitor patch release cycles for both operating systems and third-party applications to apply patches promptly.

Track Patch Compliance:

  • Implement a monitoring system to track which systems have received the latest patches and generate compliance reports.
  • Perform regular audits to ensure that all critical systems are patched according to the defined policy.

Maintain Backup Before Applying Patches:

  • Ensure that a backup of the server and critical data is taken before applying patches, to facilitate recovery in case of issues.

By ensuring that all server software is regularly updated with the latest security patches, organizations can significantly reduce their exposure to security vulnerabilities.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

countermeasure.name: Install and configure antivirus and IDS/IPS systems
countermeasure.desc:
Install and maintain antivirus software and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) on internal servers to monitor and protect against malware attacks. These systems detect, prevent, and alert on malicious activities by analyzing server traffic and system behavior. Regularly update antivirus signatures and IDS/IPS rules to enhance their effectiveness in identifying new threats. Ensure that alerts are reviewed promptly to take immediate action against potential malware infections.

Implementation Steps:

Install Antivirus Software:

  • Deploy antivirus software on all internal servers to scan for and eliminate known malware.
  • Ensure that automatic updates for antivirus definitions are enabled to keep the system up-to-date.

Configure IDS/IPS:

  • Set up intrusion detection/prevention systems to monitor network traffic and server behavior for suspicious activities.
  • Regularly update IDS/IPS signatures and detection rules to stay ahead of emerging threats.

Configure Alerting and Logging:

  • Set up alerts for any detected malware or suspicious activities to notify system administrators immediately.
  • Ensure that detailed logs are maintained for all detected events to allow for post-incident analysis and troubleshooting.

Regular Updates and Patching:

  • Schedule routine updates for both antivirus and IDS/IPS software to ensure vulnerabilities are patched and signatures are up to date.
  • Perform periodic reviews of the effectiveness of the systems in place.

Test Effectiveness:

  • Run periodic tests and simulations to ensure that antivirus and IDS/IPS systems are identifying threats effectively and responding in real time.

By implementing antivirus and IDS/IPS systems, developers and DevOps engineers can minimize the risk of malware infections and ensure continuous monitoring of the internal server environment.

References:

  • Basic Intrusion Prevention System

countermeasure.name: Restrict physical access with security measures
countermeasure.desc:
Implement strict physical security measures to restrict unauthorized access to servers and sensitive areas. Use biometric authentication, CCTV surveillance, and secure facility access policies to control who can access critical systems. Ensure that only authorized personnel can enter data centers or server rooms, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or physical damage to the servers.

Implementation Steps:

Install Biometric Authentication:

  • Implement biometric systems (e.g., fingerprint or retina scans) to control access to sensitive areas like server rooms and data centers.
  • Ensure biometric systems are integrated with facility access control systems to track and log access attempts.

Set Up CCTV Surveillance:

  • Deploy CCTV cameras at key entry points and throughout sensitive areas to monitor and record access.
  • Store video footage securely and ensure it is reviewed periodically for security threats or breaches.

Establish Secure Access Policies:

  • Create access control policies that define who is authorized to enter critical areas and under what conditions.
  • Ensure that all access is logged and periodically audited to identify unauthorized attempts.

Implement Security Personnel and Alarms:

  • Use security guards and alarm systems to monitor facility access, ensuring unauthorized individuals are immediately detected.
  • Integrate alarm systems with access logs to trigger alerts if unauthorized access is attempted.

Enforce Role-Based Physical Access:

  • Limit access to the most sensitive areas to personnel with a need-to-know basis, using role-based access controls for physical access.

By applying physical security measures, organizations can prevent unauthorized physical access to critical infrastructure, reducing the risk of tampering, theft, or other malicious activities.

References:

  • Physical and Environmental Security

countermeasure.name: Use DDoS protection services and traffic filtering
countermeasure.desc:
Implement DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering to defend against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. These measures help mitigate the impact of overwhelming traffic on the internal server by filtering malicious traffic, controlling the rate of incoming requests, and redirecting suspicious traffic to secure environments for analysis. Regularly update and configure these services to adapt to evolving attack techniques.

Implementation Steps:

Enable DDoS Protection Services:

  • Use cloud-based DDoS protection services, such as AWS Shield, Azure DDoS Protection, or Google Cloud Armor, to detect and mitigate large-scale attacks.
  • Configure the service to automatically detect and mitigate traffic spikes that may indicate a DDoS attack.

Implement Rate Limiting:

  • Set up rate limiting to restrict the number of requests that can be made to the server within a specific time frame, preventing an overload of the serverâ€™s resources.
  • Use API gateways or web application firewalls (WAF) to enforce rate limits for critical services.

Configure Traffic Filtering:

  • Implement traffic filtering mechanisms to block malicious traffic and allow only legitimate requests from trusted sources.
  • Use tools like Web Application Firewalls (WAF) or reverse proxies to filter out harmful traffic, such as SQL injection attempts or bot traffic.

Monitor Traffic for Anomalies:

  • Set up real-time traffic monitoring to detect anomalies such as sudden spikes in traffic or unusual request patterns.
  • Use centralized logging and alerting systems to notify security teams of potential DDoS attacks.

Regularly Test and Update Protection Mechanisms:

  • Regularly perform stress tests to assess the effectiveness of DDoS protection services and traffic filtering configurations.
  • Keep DDoS protection systems updated with the latest detection rules and algorithms to defend against new attack vectors.

By implementing DDoS protection services, rate limiting, and traffic filtering, developers and DevOps engineers can significantly reduce the risk and impact of DDoS attacks, ensuring better availability and stability of internal services.

References:

  • Denial of Service Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use encryption protocols for data in transit and data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Use strong encryption protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security) for data in transit and ensure that data at rest is encrypted with secure algorithms like AES (Advanced Encryption Standard). Encryption protects sensitive information from unauthorized access, both during transmission over the network and when stored on servers. Regularly review encryption configurations and update protocols to ensure they comply with the latest security standards and prevent vulnerabilities.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS for Data in Transit:

  • Configure all server communication (e.g., HTTP, API calls) to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Ensure certificates are valid, up to date, and issued by trusted certificate authorities (CAs).
  • Enforce strong ciphers and disable outdated versions (e.g., SSL, TLS 1.0/1.1) to ensure secure communication.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Use strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES-256) to encrypt sensitive data stored on the server, including databases, file systems, and backups.
  • Store encryption keys in a secure key management system (KMS) to prevent unauthorized access.

Configure Key Management:

  • Implement a secure process for key generation, storage, and rotation.
  • Ensure that encryption keys are rotated periodically and are not hardcoded in the application code.

Monitor and Audit Encryption Configurations:

  • Regularly audit encryption settings to ensure compliance with industry standards and organizational policies.
  • Use automated tools to monitor encryption protocols and identify any weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Stay Updated with Encryption Standards:

  • Regularly review and update encryption methods and algorithms to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  • Ensure that encryption methods are aligned with regulatory requirements, such as GDPR or PCI DSS.

By applying encryption for both data in transit and data at rest, developers and DevOps engineers can protect sensitive information and reduce the risk of unauthorized access.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers execute DoS/DDoS attacks to disrupt services
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

DoS/DDoS attacks aim to overwhelm a serverâ€™s resources, making it unavailable for legitimate users, disrupting critical services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers using botnets or other methods to flood the server.
  • Internal Attackers: Malicious employees or compromised internal devices initiating attacks.
  • Vectors: Botnets, SYN floods, UDP floods, and amplification attacks.

Impacts

  • Downtime: The server becomes unavailable, halting business operations.
  • Resource Exhaustion: Depletion of server resources leading to slowdowns or crashes.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Botnet DDoS: Thousands of compromised devices flood the server with traffic, causing overload.
  • Application Layer Attack: Attackers target web services with requests to consume server resources.
